Description: Mould-made (amuletic?) figure in glazed composition, representing an ithyphallic figure of naked youth, probably Harpocrates (Horus-the-Child); seated upright, looking forward; holding his colossal phallus with both hands to his side, coiled over the shoulder; rather crude modelling; pale blue turquoise glaze; pale yellow porous core; feet and extremity of phallus lost.
Curator's comments: 'Naukratic' figurines which support a grotesquely enlarged phallus were named after early finds like this example, and regarded as both un-Egyptian in type and too indecent to display. It is now clear that they form a coherent group of important figurines, probably produced locally already in the Late Period and into Roman times. Many examples from Naukratis are made in limestone and terracotta, with a few specimens in faience, such as this one. When made out of faience and of small size, they could be worn as an amulet (Herrmann et al. 2010, 67, type 32). Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.101) (phase 3)
